text:
Nick Saban wonâ€™t be the G.O.A.T.


Part 1: The NFL Draft


By: Ben Leathers


2023-04-17


Clickbait headline aside, Nick Saban is unquestionably the greatest coach in history. However, the interesting thing about â€œall timeâ€ is that it includes the future. While many think Saban will be the G.O.A.T., Kirby Smart, whoâ€™s coming off of back to back national championships, is seven years down a war path aimed at claiming the G.O.A.T. title.


There are many apects of a coachâ€™s career that will be referenced when fans engage in the G.O.A.T. debate, and I look forward to exploring them all, but with the 2023 NFL Draft happening next week and Kirby Smart coming off a record setting year with fifteen players drafted in 2022, I wanted to wet the series whistle with a focus on the NFL Draft production for their respective careers. Letâ€™s begin with Kirby, whose head coaching career began in 2016.


How well has UGA put players into the draft while Kirby Smart has been the head coach?






Wowâ€¦ could that â€œup and to the rightâ€ trajectory suggest that Kirbyâ€™s good at player development?


You might be thinking to yourselfâ€¦ â€œNo, it just suggests heâ€™s recruiting better playersâ€ which is a reasonable thing to think. Mark Richt is no question a DGD (â€œDamn Good Dawgâ€, for any non-Georgia fans), and he elevated the program during his tenure. That being said, Kirby inherited a roster whose previous three recruiting classes had an average ranking of ~9th in the country, whereas Kirby has averaged rankings of ~3rd as head coach of UGA. So you would be justified to argue that this upward trajectory just points to better recruiting. But is there more to the story?






Itâ€™s not just better players. Even recruits rated 3-stars or lower are more likely to get drafted the longer they play under Kirby.


How do UGAâ€™s Draft results during Kirbyâ€™s first 6 years compare to other coachâ€™s first 6 years?






Seeing Jimbo Fisher at #5 was surprising to begin with, but then I remembered he had a reputation for recruiting even before NIL deals were on the table. Thankfully, with the advent of the transfer portal heâ€™s also developing a reputation for losing big name recruits (Iâ€™m looking forward to watching Deyon â€œSmokeâ€ Bouie don the red and black this fall.). You could argue that Jimboâ€™s ranking on that list undermines the validity of using NFL draft production as a proxy for coaching ability, but that certainly wonâ€™t stop fans from including draft results in their G.O.A.T. debates, so weâ€™ll press on.


As a Georgia fan, I want to give a tip of the cap to Mark Richt at #6. He was a great coach who put a lot of talent into the NFL.


So how did Larry Coker and Jim Tressel out perform Kirby in the first 6 years?






Oh, they stepped into programs with loaded rosters that put 8 and 11 players into the NFL in year 1. Kirby didnâ€™t inherit a desolate roster, but it was certainly more modest.


How many UGA players will need to be drafted in order for Kirby to jump into first in year 7?






With 13 UGA players declared for this yearâ€™s draft and pundits projecting 6 UGA players to go in the first 3 rounds alone, Kirby will almost certainly be sitting atop the year-7 draft production rankings by the conclusion of the 7th round.


(Sidebar) What Happened to Larry Coker?


Wasnâ€™t he tied for first with 47 players drafted in his first 6 years as a head coach? Turns out he got fired from Miami after going 6-6 in 2006 and he didnâ€™t coach again until 2012 when he was hired by UTSA.


Letâ€™s check on some coaches that are noticibly absent from the top ten.






In fairness to Saban he didnâ€™t start his head coaching career at a blue blood football school, so lets compare the results from his start at each of the schoolâ€™s heâ€™s coached at.









Kirbyâ€™s start at UGA is out pacing any of Sabanâ€™s starts. However, we donâ€™t call him the greatest in history for no reason, so letâ€™s see how things compare when we look at ANY 6 year spanâ€¦



And there it is. Saban has spent the last 11 years churning out NFL talent at an unprecedented level, and thus he currently occupies the top 6 spots in that ranking.


So while Kirby has certainly gotten the flywheel of talent acquisition and player development up to speed quicker than anyone else, the path to G.O.A.T. status is veeeery long. The natural next question is: can he sustain? According to his post G-Day press conference last weekend, UGA is â€œbuilt to sustainâ€¦ Thatâ€™s my motto.â€, and by all accounts that looks to be the case.


To close, letâ€™s take a look at Sabanâ€™s career in itâ€™s entirety to see just how long that war path really is.






Wow. That puts â€œsustainâ€ into perspective. Saban has over 25 years as a head coach, and heâ€™s sustained greatness over that span. Kirby has gotten off to an elite start. Only time will tell if heâ€™ll be able to sustain long enough to cement himself as the G.O.A.T. Iâ€™d bet on him.



Takeaways:


Kirbyâ€™s program develops players.


Kirbyâ€™s Death Star might not have even been fully operational yetâ€¦ ğŸ¤¯


â€œAll Timeâ€ includes the future, and while Saban might be the greatest in history, Kirby is on the path to take over and when itâ€™s all said and doneâ€¦


Saban will not be the G.O.A.T., Kirby will.


If you are interested in more content like this, follow me on twitter @LeathersHead.


This analysis was based on an open source dataset, cfbd, and while Iâ€™m confident in my work, I am also confident Iâ€™m human, so if you find a mistake, please let me know.
